props.name: breakpoint
props.description: Optional breakpoint name.

props.name: media
props.description: The media query for the breakpoint.

props.name: url
props.description: The url for the background image.

props.name: id
props.description: A unique id for the background image html element.

props.name: as
props.description: The HTML tag or React component to use as the wrapper. Defaults to `<div>`.

props.name: preload
props.description:
Optional prop for preloading the background image. This works similar to the `priority` prop on the Next.js image.
Should be used for any `<BackgroundImage />` component that is above the fold, and flagged as the Largest Contentful Paint (LCP).
remarks:
[important] For preloading to work properly, media queries on `<link rel="preload">` elements cannot overlap.
Media queries on `<link rel="preload">` elements do not function the way they do on HTML elements.
The user agent will look at multiple `<link rel="preload">` media queries and find multiple matches if there is any overlap in the media queries.
This can lead to performance issues, where multiple images are preloaded.

To avoid this, the `<BackgroundImage />` component will automatically adjust the media queries set on the preload links, by adding or subtracting 1 px.
If this functionality causes any issues, it can be disabled with the `normalizeMediaQueries` prop.

props.name: images
props.description: An array of image objects of the `BackgroundImageOptions` type.

props.name: className
props.description: Optional prop for any CSS class name(s) for the background image element.

props.name: style
props.description: Optional prop for any CSS style properties for the background image element.

props.name: children
props.description: Optional child elements to render inside the component.

props.name: normalizeMediaQueries
props.description: Optional prop to disable the component from normalizing the media queries to remove overlaps. Defaults to `true`

props.name: src
props.description: The URL of the image source. The value must be a path string or a statically imported file.

props.name: width
props.description: The width prop functions the same way as it does on the Next.js `<Image />` component.
remarks: [quote] The width property represents the intrinsic image width in pixels. This property is used to infer the correct aspect ratio of the image and avoid layout shift during loading. It does not determine the rendered size of the image, which is controlled by CSS, similar to the width attribute in the HTML `` tag. [link] https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/api-reference/components/image#width-and-height | Source: Next.js Image API Reference

props.name: height
props.description: The height prop functions the same way as it does on the Next.js `<Image />` component.
remarks: [quote] The height property represents the intrinsic image height in pixels. This property is used to infer the correct aspect ratio of the image and avoid layout shift during loading. It does not determine the rendered size of the image, which is controlled by CSS, similar to the width attribute in the HTML `` tag. [link] https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/api-reference/components/image#width-and-height | Source: Next.js Image API Reference

props.name: media
props.description: The media query to be used for the fallback image, if preload is true.

props.name: preload
props.description:
Optional prop for preloading the image. This works similar to the `priority` prop on the Next.js Image component.
Should be used for any `<Picture />` component that is above the fold, and flagged as the Largest Contentful Paint (LCP).
remarks:
[important] For preloading to work properly, media queries on `<link rel="preload">` elements cannot overlap.
Media queries on `<link rel="preload">` elements do not function the way they do on HTML elements.
The user agent will look at multiple `<link rel="preload">` media queries and find multiple matches if there is any overlap in the media queries.
This can lead to performance issues, where multiple images are preloaded.
To avoid this, the `<Picture />` component will automatically adjust the media queries set on Source to remove any overlap,
by adding or subtracting 1 px. If this functionality causes any issues, it can be disabled with the `normalizeMediaQueries` prop.

props.name: fallbackMedia
props.description: An optional prop, to set the fallback media query for preloading.

props.name: normalizeMediaQueries
props.description: An optional prop to disable the component from normalizing the media queries to remove overlap.

props.name: children
props.type: React.ReactElement<SourceProps, string | React.JSXElementConstructor<any>>[] | React.ReactElement<ImgProps, string | React.JSXElementConstructor<any>>
props.description: Optional child elements to render inside the component.

props.name: sizes
props.description: The sizes attribute defining image display sizes for different viewports.

props.name: srcSet
props.description: The srcset attribute specifying multiple image sources for responsive loading.

props.name: src
props.description: The image source URL.

props.name: media
props.description: Optional media query.

props.name: data
props.description: An array of image attributes.
